attributes.title: The effect of attention cued to rewards or punishments on action invigoration and suppression
attributes.description: Project with 2 Bachelor students testing whether biasing people's attention towards prospective positive/ negative outcomes affects their ability to perform Go/ NoGo actions

q2.value:
1)	Attention to rewards facilitates a Go response, and attention to punishments facilitates a NoGo responses. This hypothesis will be tested as a main effect of cue position (cue presented on the side of rewards/ punishments) on choices (Go/ NoGo).
2)	The instruction to look at rewards when required to perform a Go response and to look at punishments when required to perform a NoGo response enhances performance. This hypothesis will be tested as an interaction effect between cue position (cue presented on the side of rewards/ punishments) and instructions (before/ after instructions) on choices (Go/ NoGo): there should be a weaker main effect of cue position after compared to before instructions.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q5.value:
There will be no between-subjects factors.
Every subject is exposed to all possible conditions in a 2 (Go/ NoGo cue) x 2 (cue on reward/ punishment side) x 2 (before/ after instructions) design. Every subject will complete 1 of 10 pseudo-randomized trial orders, each featuring a random mapping between task stimuli and task conditions. Subjects and personnel will neither be aware of the exact trial order during the study, nor the assignment of stimuli to conditions (until subjects learn the response requirement of each cue). There will be no interaction between personnel and subjects during performance of the task.

question.value:
The study is a 2 (required response: Go /NoGo) x 2 (cue on reward/ punishment side) x 2 (before/ after instructions) fully-within (repeated measures) design. 
Each subject will be exposed to 28 trials in each condition (224 trials in total).

q7.value: Each subject is exposed to all 8 task conditions (Go/NoGo x cue on reward/ punishment side x before/ after instructions). Each condition contains the same amount of trials. Each subject will complete one of 10 pseudo-randomized trial orders (with the restriction that one cue cannot be presented at the same location on more than 2 consecutive trials). Stimuli will be randomly assigned to task conditions for each trial order.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will use human subjects mostly from a student population at Radboud University, the Netherlands, as well as from the social network of the involved researchers. Subjects are required to be at least 18 years old, speak and understand the English language, not be color-blind, and perform the task via a desktop PC/ laptop featuring a keyboard. The task will be administered online via the platform Gorilla. Subjects will be recruited through the university’s SONA study recruitment system. 
Subjects will be offered 1 h of study credit for compensation. Based on their performance, they will additionally receive tickets for a lottery with the chance to win one of two vouchers (worth 20€) at the end the project. Subjects receive vouchers only if they achieve at least 60% accuracy. Beyond this threshold, they receive tickets proportional to the points gained in the task, such that more earned points lead to a higher chance to win one of the vouchers. Data collection will start on April 22, 2020 and last until May 10, 2020.

q11.value: Data will be collected as part of a Bachelor thesis research project. We are thus limited both by the allocated data collection phase of two weeks (April 22 – May 10) and by the number of tokens we received from our institution to retrieve data from the Gorilla platform. Given we received 60 tokens (of which 5 were already used for internal pilot purposes), we aim at a sample size of N = 55. Each subject will perform 224 trials of the task.

q12.value:
Data collection is constrained by the allocated data collection time and the number of tokens (N = 55) we received from our institution. 
The motivational bias in our task might be similar to the motivational bias measured in an alternative Motivational Go/NoGo Task in which cues are exclusively associated with either rewards or punishments (Swart et al., 2017, 2018). In those studies, the motivational bias, operationalized as the main effect of cue valence on proportion Go responses, has been replicated several times with samples of N = 20-40.
The effect of instructions (i.e. whether subjects are able to follow the instructions and whether doing so reduces the effect of cue position) is unknown.

q13.value: Data collection will be terminated latest on May 10, 2020, or if 55 subjects have been collected.

question.value:
For each subject, we will manipulate: 
• required action of the cue (Go vs. NoGo, within-subjects, trial-by-trial manipulation, factor) 
• side on which the cue is presented (reward vs. punishment side, within-subjects, trial-by-trial manipulation, factor)
• instructions (before/ after instructions on attentional strategy, within-subjects, block-wise manipulation: “before” for blocks 1 and 2, “after” for block 3 and 4, factor)

DVs: 
• choice (Go/NoGo; measured as subject's action—button press or no button press—on each trial) 
• reaction times (Go/NoGo; measured as latency of button press on each trial, not defined 'NA' for NoGo responses) 

Other variables for sample description and potential exploratory analyses: We will collect age, gender, handedness (all three for sample descriptives), the brief (13-item) version of the Self Control Scale (SCS; Tangney, Baumeister, & Boone, 2004), the behavioral activation system/ behavioral inhibition system scales (BIS/BAS scales; Carver & White, 1994), and two scenarios of two football coaches, one changing and the other one not changing their team after a previous win (Scenario 1) or defeat (Scenario 2), leading to a subsequent defeat (Zeelenberg, van den Bos, van Dijk, & Pieters, 2002). Subjects have to indicate which coach will experience more regret and rate for both coaches how responsible they were for the defeat (7-point scale). 

At the end, subjects will be asked in text boxes to indicate a) what they think the hypothesis of the experiment was, b) whether they used any (non-instructed) strategies to complete the task, and if so, describe them, c) whether they believe that the instructions helped them perform the task and if so, describe any “tricks” that helped them follow the instructions, and d) a free field for any further comments.

These variables are collected for exploratory purposes (see exploratory analyses). The SCS is part of individual Bachelor thesis projects on this data. We plan to report correlations between subjects’ individual main effect of cue position of proportion Go/ reaction times and questionnaire scores as exploratory analyses. Given the maximal N = 55, we would have 80% power to detect correlations of r bigger than .32 (one-sided test; computed with G*Power; Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007).
For questionnaires, we will report the mean score of all items (after reversing reversed items).

A)	Generalized linear mixed-effects models on accuracy as DV 
We will fit a generalized linear mixed effects model using the function glmer from the package lme4 in R (corresponding to a mixed-effects logistic regression). The model formula will be: 

glmer(response ~ requiredAction_f * cuePosition_f * instructions_f + (requiredAction_f * cuePosition_f * instructions_f |Subject), data = data, family = binomial()). 

We expect:
a)	A main effect of required action, reflecting that people perform more Go responses to Go than NoGo cues, i.e. they learn the task;
b)	A main effect of cue position, with more Go responses when cues are presented on the reward side than when they are presented on the punishment side, reflecting the motivational bias;
c)	An interaction effect between cue position and instructions, such that the main effect of cue position will be smaller after compared to before the instructions.

To probe in which condition(s) (i.e. Go or NoGo cues, cues on the reward or the punishment side) the instructions improved performance (selectively or particularly), we will also inspect the two-way interaction between required action and instructions and the three-way interaction between required action, cue position, and instructions. 
Two-way and three-way interactions will be followed up by using constrained models in which we restrict one of the three independent variables to only one factor level (e.g. only Go cues, only cues on the reward side, only Go cues on the reward side,…).

By default, we will NOT compute the gradient and Hessian of the nonlinear optimization solution, i.e. set control = glmerControl(calc.derivs = FALSE), because these are prone to false positive warnings. As optimizer, we will use ‘bobyqa’ by setting glmerControl(optimizer = c("bobyqa").

If the models in glmer do not converge, we will increase the number of iterations using control = glmerControl(optCtrl = list(maxfun = 1e+9)) and try out different optimizers. 

If models still do not converge, we will instead fit the same models in stan using the R package brms. We will use the same model equation, except that the corresponding link function has to be family = bernoulli(). We will use the following priors: set_prior("normal(0,2)", class = "b") set_prior("cauchy(0,2)", class = "sd") set_prior("lkj(1)", class = "cor") We will start the fitting procedure with 4 chains, with 200 warm-up iterations and 1,000 post warm-up iterations per chains (4,000 samples total). Model will be considered to have converged when the scale reduction factor is Rhat smaller than 1.1 for all parameters (Gelman & Rubin, 1992). In case model convergence was not reached, we will first increase adapt_delta up to .99, and if necessary also increase warm-up and sampling iterations will be increased up to 10,000. If models have not reached convergence until this point, we will repeat the fitting procedure while excluding subjects for whom Rhat bigger than 1.1, and report whether our results/ conclusions change after subject exclusion. We will report the percentage of samples of the respective posterior that is above or below zero. If 97.5% of a posterior (corresponding to a two-sided test) are above or below zero, we will consider this significant. 

If also this approach fails, we will adapt a two-stage least-squares approach: For each subject separately, we will fit the following logistic regression using the function glm in R: 
glm(response ~ requiredAction_f * cuePosition_f * instructions_f, data = data, family = binomial()) We will then extract all regression weights of each subject and perform one-sample t-tests to test whether those weights are significantly different from zero on a sample level. 

B)	Linear mixed-effects models on RTs as DV:
All specifications under A) apply, with the following exceptions: 
a)	Instead of the glmer() command, we will use the lmer() command 
b)	We will drop the binomial link function (no "family = binomial()"). 
c)	Similarly, instead of glm(), we will use lm() if applicable.

q18.value: We will exclude reaction times shorter than 300 ms from all analyses (as those are too fast to be induced by the presented cue). For all factors, sum-to-zero coding with be used.

q19.value:
A)	Generalized linear mixed-effects models 
For frequentist generalized linear mixed-effects models with glmer(), we will consider p-values smaller than .05 as the cut-off for significance. 
For Bayesian generalized linear mixed-effects models with brm(), we will consider an effect as significantly different from zero if at least 97.5% of its posterior (corresponding to a two-sided test) lies above or below zero. 
For the two-stage least-squares approach, we will consider p-values smaller than .05 as the cut-off for significance. 

B)	Linear mixed-effects models
Same as under A)

q20.value: We will exclude reaction times shorter than 300 ms from all analyses (as those are too fast to be induced by the presented cue). For all factors, sum-to-zero coding with be used.

q21.value:
There are two potential criteria for excluding entire subjects: 
• Guessing the experimental hypothesis: Subjects who correctly guess the hypothesis of the experiment on first question of the funnel debriefing. 
• Insufficient learning: For each subject, we will perform a logistic regression over all trials with choice (Go/NoGo) as dependent variable and required action (Go/NoGo) as independent variable. Subjects who do not show a significant effect of required action (p < .05) might show insufficient learning. 
We will perform all analyses with and without excluding the subjects identified with these criteria, and report whether subject exclusion changes any of our conclusions.

q22.value:
A)	Effects of differences in outcome magnitude on choices
•	Previous studies using a similar paradigm, i.e. two streams of numbers presented on the left and right of the screen (Glickman, Tsetsos, & Usher, 2018; Kunar, Watson, Tsetsos, & Chater, 2017; Tsetsos, Chater, & Usher, 2012) have found that high magnitude numbers particularly attract attention. Hence, one might hypothesize that if, on a certain trial, the number of points to be gained is much higher than the number of points to be lost, participants particularly attend to the (high) rewards and thus be more likely to show a Go response. Vice versa, if the number of points to be lost is much higher than the number of points to be gained, one might hypothesize that participants particularly attend to the (high) punishments and thus be more likely to show a NoGo response. To test this hypothesis, we will calculate the difference between the points to be gained and points to be lost on every trials (signed, i.e. positive numbers indicate more points to be gained, negative numbers more points to be lost). We expect a main effect of this difference in points on choices (Go/ NoGo) such that a higher score predicts a higher chance for a Go response.
B)	Exploratory analysis on questionnaires:
•	We expect a two-way interaction effect between cue-position and SCS scores such that the effect of cue position is stronger for subjects with low SCS scores than subjects with high SCS scores.
•	We expect a two-way interaction effect between cue-position and BAS score such that the effect of cue position is stronger for subjects with higher BAS scores than subjects with lower BAS scores. Potentially though, this effect might be restricted to Go cues only, reflected in a three-way interaction between required action, cue position, and BAS scores.
•	We expect a two-way interaction effect between cue-position and BIS scores such that the effect of cue position is stronger for subjects with higher BIS scores than subjects with lower BIS scores. Potentially though, this effect might be restricted to NoGo cues only, reflected in a three-way interaction between required action, cue position, and BIS scores.
•	We will investigate the two-way interaction effects between cue position and regret judgments (coach who did/ did not change his team), reflecting whether the effect of cue position differs between participants who judge one or the other coach as more responsible.
•	We will investigate the two-way interaction effects between cue position and the difference between responsibility ratings of both coaches (coach who did/ did not change his team), reflecting whether the effect of cue position might be related to how responsible participants rate one coach compared to the other.

registration_responses.q2:
1)	Attention to rewards facilitates a Go response, and attention to punishments facilitates a NoGo responses. This hypothesis will be tested as a main effect of cue position (cue presented on the side of rewards/ punishments) on choices (Go/ NoGo).
2)	The instruction to look at rewards when required to perform a Go response and to look at punishments when required to perform a NoGo response enhances performance. This hypothesis will be tested as an interaction effect between cue position (cue presented on the side of rewards/ punishments) and instructions (before/ after instructions) on choices (Go/ NoGo): there should be a weaker main effect of cue position after compared to before instructions.
registration_responses.q3: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q4: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
registration_responses.q5:
There will be no between-subjects factors.
Every subject is exposed to all possible conditions in a 2 (Go/ NoGo cue) x 2 (cue on reward/ punishment side) x 2 (before/ after instructions) design. Every subject will complete 1 of 10 pseudo-randomized trial orders, each featuring a random mapping between task stimuli and task conditions. Subjects and personnel will neither be aware of the exact trial order during the study, nor the assignment of stimuli to conditions (until subjects learn the response requirement of each cue). There will be no interaction between personnel and subjects during performance of the task.
registration_responses.q7: Each subject is exposed to all 8 task conditions (Go/NoGo x cue on reward/ punishment side x before/ after instructions). Each condition contains the same amount of trials. Each subject will complete one of 10 pseudo-randomized trial orders (with the restriction that one cue cannot be presented at the same location on more than 2 consecutive trials). Stimuli will be randomly assigned to task conditions for each trial order.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: Data will be collected as part of a Bachelor thesis research project. We are thus limited both by the allocated data collection phase of two weeks (April 22 – May 10) and by the number of tokens we received from our institution to retrieve data from the Gorilla platform. Given we received 60 tokens (of which 5 were already used for internal pilot purposes), we aim at a sample size of N = 55. Each subject will perform 224 trials of the task.
registration_responses.q12:
Data collection is constrained by the allocated data collection time and the number of tokens (N = 55) we received from our institution. 
The motivational bias in our task might be similar to the motivational bias measured in an alternative Motivational Go/NoGo Task in which cues are exclusively associated with either rewards or punishments (Swart et al., 2017, 2018). In those studies, the motivational bias, operationalized as the main effect of cue valence on proportion Go responses, has been replicated several times with samples of N = 20-40.
The effect of instructions (i.e. whether subjects are able to follow the instructions and whether doing so reduces the effect of cue position) is unknown.
registration_responses.q13: Data collection will be terminated latest on May 10, 2020, or if 55 subjects have been collected.
registration_responses.q18: We will exclude reaction times shorter than 300 ms from all analyses (as those are too fast to be induced by the presented cue). For all factors, sum-to-zero coding with be used.
registration_responses.q19:
A)	Generalized linear mixed-effects models 
For frequentist generalized linear mixed-effects models with glmer(), we will consider p-values smaller than .05 as the cut-off for significance. 
For Bayesian generalized linear mixed-effects models with brm(), we will consider an effect as significantly different from zero if at least 97.5% of its posterior (corresponding to a two-sided test) lies above or below zero. 
For the two-stage least-squares approach, we will consider p-values smaller than .05 as the cut-off for significance. 

B)	Linear mixed-effects models
Same as under A)
registration_responses.q20: We will exclude reaction times shorter than 300 ms from all analyses (as those are too fast to be induced by the presented cue). For all factors, sum-to-zero coding with be used.
registration_responses.q21:
There are two potential criteria for excluding entire subjects: 
• Guessing the experimental hypothesis: Subjects who correctly guess the hypothesis of the experiment on first question of the funnel debriefing. 
• Insufficient learning: For each subject, we will perform a logistic regression over all trials with choice (Go/NoGo) as dependent variable and required action (Go/NoGo) as independent variable. Subjects who do not show a significant effect of required action (p < .05) might show insufficient learning. 
We will perform all analyses with and without excluding the subjects identified with these criteria, and report whether subject exclusion changes any of our conclusions.
registration_responses.q22:
A)	Effects of differences in outcome magnitude on choices
•	Previous studies using a similar paradigm, i.e. two streams of numbers presented on the left and right of the screen (Glickman, Tsetsos, & Usher, 2018; Kunar, Watson, Tsetsos, & Chater, 2017; Tsetsos, Chater, & Usher, 2012) have found that high magnitude numbers particularly attract attention. Hence, one might hypothesize that if, on a certain trial, the number of points to be gained is much higher than the number of points to be lost, participants particularly attend to the (high) rewards and thus be more likely to show a Go response. Vice versa, if the number of points to be lost is much higher than the number of points to be gained, one might hypothesize that participants particularly attend to the (high) punishments and thus be more likely to show a NoGo response. To test this hypothesis, we will calculate the difference between the points to be gained and points to be lost on every trials (signed, i.e. positive numbers indicate more points to be gained, negative numbers more points to be lost). We expect a main effect of this difference in points on choices (Go/ NoGo) such that a higher score predicts a higher chance for a Go response.
B)	Exploratory analysis on questionnaires:
•	We expect a two-way interaction effect between cue-position and SCS scores such that the effect of cue position is stronger for subjects with low SCS scores than subjects with high SCS scores.
•	We expect a two-way interaction effect between cue-position and BAS score such that the effect of cue position is stronger for subjects with higher BAS scores than subjects with lower BAS scores. Potentially though, this effect might be restricted to Go cues only, reflected in a three-way interaction between required action, cue position, and BAS scores.
•	We expect a two-way interaction effect between cue-position and BIS scores such that the effect of cue position is stronger for subjects with higher BIS scores than subjects with lower BIS scores. Potentially though, this effect might be restricted to NoGo cues only, reflected in a three-way interaction between required action, cue position, and BIS scores.
•	We will investigate the two-way interaction effects between cue position and regret judgments (coach who did/ did not change his team), reflecting whether the effect of cue position differs between participants who judge one or the other coach as more responsible.
•	We will investigate the two-way interaction effects between cue position and the difference between responsibility ratings of both coaches (coach who did/ did not change his team), reflecting whether the effect of cue position might be related to how responsible participants rate one coach compared to the other.

registration_responses.q6.question:
The study is a 2 (required response: Go /NoGo) x 2 (cue on reward/ punishment side) x 2 (before/ after instructions) fully-within (repeated measures) design. 
Each subject will be exposed to 28 trials in each condition (224 trials in total).
registration_responses.q10.question:
We will use human subjects mostly from a student population at Radboud University, the Netherlands, as well as from the social network of the involved researchers. Subjects are required to be at least 18 years old, speak and understand the English language, not be color-blind, and perform the task via a desktop PC/ laptop featuring a keyboard. The task will be administered online via the platform Gorilla. Subjects will be recruited through the university’s SONA study recruitment system. 
Subjects will be offered 1 h of study credit for compensation. Based on their performance, they will additionally receive tickets for a lottery with the chance to win one of two vouchers (worth 20€) at the end the project. Subjects receive vouchers only if they achieve at least 60% accuracy. Beyond this threshold, they receive tickets proportional to the points gained in the task, such that more earned points lead to a higher chance to win one of the vouchers. Data collection will start on April 22, 2020 and last until May 10, 2020.
registration_responses.q14.question:
For each subject, we will manipulate: 
• required action of the cue (Go vs. NoGo, within-subjects, trial-by-trial manipulation, factor) 
• side on which the cue is presented (reward vs. punishment side, within-subjects, trial-by-trial manipulation, factor)
• instructions (before/ after instructions on attentional strategy, within-subjects, block-wise manipulation: “before” for blocks 1 and 2, “after” for block 3 and 4, factor)
registration_responses.q15.question:
DVs: 
• choice (Go/NoGo; measured as subject's action—button press or no button press—on each trial) 
• reaction times (Go/NoGo; measured as latency of button press on each trial, not defined 'NA' for NoGo responses) 

Other variables for sample description and potential exploratory analyses: We will collect age, gender, handedness (all three for sample descriptives), the brief (13-item) version of the Self Control Scale (SCS; Tangney, Baumeister, & Boone, 2004), the behavioral activation system/ behavioral inhibition system scales (BIS/BAS scales; Carver & White, 1994), and two scenarios of two football coaches, one changing and the other one not changing their team after a previous win (Scenario 1) or defeat (Scenario 2), leading to a subsequent defeat (Zeelenberg, van den Bos, van Dijk, & Pieters, 2002). Subjects have to indicate which coach will experience more regret and rate for both coaches how responsible they were for the defeat (7-point scale). 

At the end, subjects will be asked in text boxes to indicate a) what they think the hypothesis of the experiment was, b) whether they used any (non-instructed) strategies to complete the task, and if so, describe them, c) whether they believe that the instructions helped them perform the task and if so, describe any “tricks” that helped them follow the instructions, and d) a free field for any further comments.

These variables are collected for exploratory purposes (see exploratory analyses). The SCS is part of individual Bachelor thesis projects on this data. We plan to report correlations between subjects’ individual main effect of cue position of proportion Go/ reaction times and questionnaire scores as exploratory analyses. Given the maximal N = 55, we would have 80% power to detect correlations of r bigger than .32 (one-sided test; computed with G*Power; Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007).
registration_responses.q16.question: For questionnaires, we will report the mean score of all items (after reversing reversed items).
registration_responses.q17.question:
A)	Generalized linear mixed-effects models on accuracy as DV 
We will fit a generalized linear mixed effects model using the function glmer from the package lme4 in R (corresponding to a mixed-effects logistic regression). The model formula will be: 

glmer(response ~ requiredAction_f * cuePosition_f * instructions_f + (requiredAction_f * cuePosition_f * instructions_f |Subject), data = data, family = binomial()). 

We expect:
a)	A main effect of required action, reflecting that people perform more Go responses to Go than NoGo cues, i.e. they learn the task;
b)	A main effect of cue position, with more Go responses when cues are presented on the reward side than when they are presented on the punishment side, reflecting the motivational bias;
c)	An interaction effect between cue position and instructions, such that the main effect of cue position will be smaller after compared to before the instructions.

To probe in which condition(s) (i.e. Go or NoGo cues, cues on the reward or the punishment side) the instructions improved performance (selectively or particularly), we will also inspect the two-way interaction between required action and instructions and the three-way interaction between required action, cue position, and instructions. 
Two-way and three-way interactions will be followed up by using constrained models in which we restrict one of the three independent variables to only one factor level (e.g. only Go cues, only cues on the reward side, only Go cues on the reward side,…).

By default, we will NOT compute the gradient and Hessian of the nonlinear optimization solution, i.e. set control = glmerControl(calc.derivs = FALSE), because these are prone to false positive warnings. As optimizer, we will use ‘bobyqa’ by setting glmerControl(optimizer = c("bobyqa").

If the models in glmer do not converge, we will increase the number of iterations using control = glmerControl(optCtrl = list(maxfun = 1e+9)) and try out different optimizers. 

If models still do not converge, we will instead fit the same models in stan using the R package brms. We will use the same model equation, except that the corresponding link function has to be family = bernoulli(). We will use the following priors: set_prior("normal(0,2)", class = "b") set_prior("cauchy(0,2)", class = "sd") set_prior("lkj(1)", class = "cor") We will start the fitting procedure with 4 chains, with 200 warm-up iterations and 1,000 post warm-up iterations per chains (4,000 samples total). Model will be considered to have converged when the scale reduction factor is Rhat smaller than 1.1 for all parameters (Gelman & Rubin, 1992). In case model convergence was not reached, we will first increase adapt_delta up to .99, and if necessary also increase warm-up and sampling iterations will be increased up to 10,000. If models have not reached convergence until this point, we will repeat the fitting procedure while excluding subjects for whom Rhat bigger than 1.1, and report whether our results/ conclusions change after subject exclusion. We will report the percentage of samples of the respective posterior that is above or below zero. If 97.5% of a posterior (corresponding to a two-sided test) are above or below zero, we will consider this significant. 

If also this approach fails, we will adapt a two-stage least-squares approach: For each subject separately, we will fit the following logistic regression using the function glm in R: 
glm(response ~ requiredAction_f * cuePosition_f * instructions_f, data = data, family = binomial()) We will then extract all regression weights of each subject and perform one-sample t-tests to test whether those weights are significantly different from zero on a sample level. 

B)	Linear mixed-effects models on RTs as DV:
All specifications under A) apply, with the following exceptions: 
a)	Instead of the glmer() command, we will use the lmer() command 
b)	We will drop the binomial link function (no "family = binomial()"). 
c)	Similarly, instead of glm(), we will use lm() if applicable.

question10b.value:
Procedure:
All the participants are asked to take part to an online session. After giving their consensus for the processing of their personal data they will be asked to fill the Personality Assessment Inventory-Borderline (PAI-BOR; Morey, 1991). After that the participants are asked to complete Trust Appraisal of neutral faces task. After the task participants are asked to complete the Justice Sensitivity Inventory (Schmitt et al. 2010). 

Material: 
1.	Borderline Personality Features assessment with Personality Assessment Inventory-Borderline (PAI-BOR) (Morey, 1991) The PAI is a 344 item self-report measure of personality which has been shown to be a reliable measure in assessing BP. The respondent is asked to select the response that best pertains to them. Responses to be endorsed are either False/not at all true, Slightly True, Mainly True, or Very True. The Borderline section (PAI-BOR) is composed by 24 items corresponding to 4 subscales: affective instability (BOR-A,), identify problems (BOR-I, 6 items), negative relationships (BOR-N, 6 items) and self harm (BOR-S, 6 items).
2.	Justice Sensitivity Inventory (Schmitt, Baumert, Gollwitzer & Maes, 2010): self-report inventory for measuring individual differences in four components of justice sensitivity. The inventory gives four different scores varying between 1 and 6: victim sensitivity, observer sensitivity, beneficiary sensitivity, and perpetrator sensitivity. Because beneficiary, observer, and perpetrator sensitivity are closely related, these scores are often collapsed to create a measure of other-oriented sensitivity (Edele, Dziobek & Keller, 2013). 
3.     Trust Appraisal: participants are asked to rate on a 7-point Likert scale the trustworthiness of each of 16 black and white photographs of unfamiliar Caucasian faces presented in a random order. We used 16 different identities (8 male and 8 female) that were selected running two pretests. The first pretest consisted of 30 undergraduate female students (M Age = 23.2, SD = 2.2) selecting the stimulus they detected as “mildly happy” along a continuum of 21 pictures created through morphing from neutral expression to happy expression for 16 different identities (8 female, 8 male) from the NimStim database. The second pretest consisted of 17 undergraduate female students (M Age = 24.4, SD = 2.4) rating the average frame chosen for each identity in the previous test on the two dimensions of trustworthiness and attractiveness. We selected a pool of 8 couples of stimuli (4 female couples, 4 male couples) similar on trustworthiness and attractiveness dimensions.

question1a.value:
1.	Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) features correlate with Justice Sensitivity (JS) 
2.	Lower trust appraisal predicted by JS
3.	Gender of the participants moderates the link occurring between BPD features and trust appraisal within a mediation model with JS mediator of the link between BPD features and trust appraisal only for male neutral faces and not female ones.

question2a.value: We expect an interaction effect between the gender of the participants, and the BPD traits on trust appraisal of neutral male faces and not female ones. We expect to replicate the effect found in an exploratory phases of the previous pre-registered study (https://osf.io/axz36) so that in the female sample increasing BPD features the appraisal of trust of neutral male faces decreases. This did not occur for female neutral faces and not for the male sample. When we pre-registered the previous protocol we did not include such hypothesis however from the results it appears that this is a worth testing hypothesis.

question1c.value: Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) features correlate with Justice Sensitivity (JS).

attributes.title: SARS-CoV-2 (2019-nCoV) 3CLpro Model & Screening
attributes.description: SARS-CoV-2 (2019-nCoV) 3CLpro model, virtual screening results and docking models

summary.value: This data project contains the Virtual Screening folder: model of SARS-CoV-2 3CLpro, screening/docking results of model A, B chains and those of the crystal structure. The Extended Results folder: SARS-CoV-2 substrate specificity, model 3D views, screening summary of crystal structure, comparison of models and crystal structure active sites. This registration has Table S2 revised (v2) and is captured before revision on F1000Research.
